Aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol over mesoporous Mn-doped ceria supported Au nanoparticle catalyst Sandip Mandal a Chiranjit Santra a Kyoko K. Bando b Olusola O. James a c Sudip Maity c Devinder Mehta d Biswajit Chowdhury a ⁎ a Department of Applied Chemistry, Indian School of Mines, Dhanbad, India Department of Applied Chemistry, Indian School of Mines Dhanbad India b Nanosystem Research Institute, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science & Technology (AIST), Tsukuba, Japan Nanosystem Research Institute, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science & Technology (AIST) Tsukuba Japan c Central Institute of Mining & Fuel Research (CIMFR), Dhanbad, India Central Institute of Mining & Fuel Research (CIMFR) Dhanbad India d Department of Physics, Punjab University, Chandigarh, India Department of Physics, Punjab University Chandigarh India ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +91 326 2235663; fax: +91 326 2296563. Graphical abstract In this decade intensive research was carried out to prepare mesoporous non-silicious oxide for various application. Development of mesoporous ceria based material has become most important because of its application in catalysis, solar cell and photovoltic cell. The selective aerobic oxidation of primary alcohols through an environment benign route to synthesize aldehydes is of utmost importance. The catalytic role of supported gold nanoparticles for aerobic oxidation reaction has been focused in the era of sustainable chemistry. The unique redox property of ceria is a fascination for developing Au–CeO2 catalyst in many studies on aerobic oxidation reaction. In this work, we have prepared mesoporous manganese doped ceria to examine the change of physicochemical properties due to incorporation of managnese to the ceria lattice. Deposition of gold nanoparticles and Mn-doping on ceria enhanced the redox behaviour of ceria as well as the basic properties. A thorough characterization by BET S.A., XRD, Raman, HRTEM, STEM, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, XPS, XAFS reveal the distortion of in the doped CeO2 lattice is electronic in nature rather than structural distortion. The catalytic activity of the catalysts demonstrate the promotional role of gold nanoparticle in this study. Keywords Mesoporous Gold Manganese Oxidation Ceria 1 Introduction Ceria based material has been widely investigated in this decade because of its use in solar cell, fuel cell, metal oxide semiconductor devices and as three way catalyst [1]. Oxygen storage capacities (OSC) of ceria are related to its reducibility which in turn depends on the size of its crystallites. Doping with lower valent cations also a common strategy for tuning reducibility and OSC of ceria at low temperature applications [2–4]. The enhancement of OSC of CeO2 due to introduction of dopant is usually attributed to the distortion of fluorite structure of CeO2. Structural distortion of fluorite lattice may influence the reducibility of both dopant and host ion [5]. However the increase in OSC of host oxide may be due to change in the electronic state of the dopant ions [6]. After extensive work on mesoporous silica as a catalyst for various reactions [7–9] the development of mesoporous non-silicious oxides needs to be cultivated widely as the diffusion of reactants and products are more effective leading to high catalytic activity [10]. A recent report by Postole et al. [11] revealed that doping can as well influence surface acid-base properties of mesoporous ceria–zirconia and its catalytic behaviour. Among different reactions, selective liquid phase aerobic oxidation of alcohols to corresponding carbonyl compounds using solid catalysts under mild condition is a shared desire from both economics and environmental perspectives [12,13]. Till the breakthrough discovery by Haruta et al. the chemistry of gold nanoparticles is well nurtured by different groups for different reaction, e.g. propylene epoxidation, CO oxidation, alcohol oxidation, hydrogenation reaction, etc. [14–16]. Catalytic performance of Au nanoparticles for alcohols oxidation was found to be influenced by the nature of support materials and preparation methods [17,18]. The preparation method determines the dispersion and particle distribution, while nature of support materials can influence morphology and electronic state of the Au nanoparticles [19]. Moreover surface acid–base property [20,21] and lattice oxygen vacancy [22–24] of supports materials have been linked for enhancing the performance of Au nanoparticle catalysts during alcohols oxidation reactions [25]. There is an attraction to use ceria as support for gold nanoparticles in oxidation reactions because of interaction between gold nanoparticles and ceria via its lattice oxygen vacancy. In a recent works done by our group [26,27] the change in the electronic and chemical properties of metal doped mesoporous ceria (M–CeO2; M=Ba2+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Sm3+) supported gold nanoparticle demonstrating different activity towards aerobic benzyl alcohol oxidation reaction. As a dopant to ceria, manganese (Mn2+) has been widely studied for several oxidation reactions [28]. The Mn–CeO2 supported gold nanoparticle was studied for CO oxidation reaction however there is no report on the dual role of gold and manganese for aerobic benzyl alcohol oxidation reaction. After scrutinizing these observations an attempt was taken to investigate the morphology, electronic, redox and acid-base properties of mesoporous manganese doped ceria supported gold nanoparticles catalyst useful for the benzyl alcohol oxidation reaction. The three different catalysts Mn–CeO2 (Mn/Ce=2/100), Mn–CeO2 (Mn/Ce=6/100) and 3.5wt% Au/Mn–CeO2 (Mn/Ce=6/100) have been prepared and characterized by BET S.A., XRD, Raman, HRTEM, STEM, XPS, XAFS, TPR, and CO2-TPD techniques. The catalytic performances of the manganese and gold doped ceria catalyst are correlated with the characterization results. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of Mn doped CeO2 support material The support material, i.e. manganese doped cerium oxide was prepared by the non-hydrothermal sol–gel method. In this procedure the solution of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (Aldrich) was added to triethanolamine (Acros) under stirring condition at room temperature. After complete addition of cerium nitrate solution, manganese acetate (Qualigens) in solid form was added to it with constant stirring. This total content was stirred for 10min after that tetraethylammonium hydroxide (Merck, Germany) was added dropwise. The solution kept in constant stirring condition at RT resulting the final gel composition of triethanolamine:Ce(NO3)3·6H2O:H2O:Mn(OAc)2:tetraethylammonium hydroxide is 0.2:0.1:1.1:0.006:0.1 (molar ratio). The gel material was dried at 110°C for 24h and it was calcined at 700°C for 10h with temperature ramp of 1°C/min. 2.1.2 Deposition of gold on support material The gold nanoparticles were deposited on the support following the procedure reported by Chowdhury et al. [26,27,29]. In this typical procedure 150ml deionized water was taken in a beaker and required amount of HAuCl4·4H2O (Aldrich) was added to it. Afterwards the PH of the solution was maintained at 7.0 by adding NaOH and temperature was increased up to 70°C. After attaining the temperature at 70°C, the support material was added and the mixture was kept in stirred condition for 1h. Then the material was filtered off and washed with water. Afterwards it was dried in vacuum followed by calcinations at 300°C for 4h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 BET surface area and porosity measurement The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm of the sample was measured at liquid nitrogen temperature with a Quantachrome Autosorb-1C-TPD at 77K. Pre-treatment of the samples were done at 473K for 3h under high vacuum. The surface area was determined by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation. 2.2.2 X-ray diffraction (XRD) XRD patterns are recorded at room temperature on a D8 ADVANCE (BRUKER AXS, Germany) diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation with parallel beam (Gobel Mirror). The details of the experimentation and data analysis can be found elsewhere [26]. 2.2.3 Raman spectroscopy The Raman spectra was recorded at room temperature on an HR 800 Raman spectrophotometer (Jobin Yvon Horiba, France) using monochromatic radiation emitted by a He–Ne laser (633nm), operating at 50mW and with a spectral resolution of 0.3cm−1. 2.2.4 High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and scanning tunneling electron microscopy (STEM) HRTEM image of the of the catalysts was obtained on JEOL JEM 2100 microscope operated at 200kV acceleration voltage using Lacey carbon coated Cu grid of 300 mess size. STEM used was from Oxford Instruments (model x-sight). 2.2.5 Energy dispersive X-ray fluorescence (EDXRF) An EDXRF analysis was carried out to determine the gold content in the sample. The spectrometer is basically built together with 3kW long-fine-focus 42Mo-anode X-ray diffraction tube and 4kW X-ray generator procured from Pan Analytic. A collimated beam from the X-ray tube was used to excite the target. A Si(Li)/LEGe detector (FWHM=160eV at Mn Kα X-rays, Canberra, US) in the horizontal configuration coupled with a PC based multichannel analyzer was used to collect the fluorescent X-ray spectra. 2.2.6 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) XPS analysis of the catalysts was carried out with a PHI-5500 spectrometer with Al Kα radiation (1253.6eV) operated in pass energy 50eV. The samples were degassed out for several hours in XPS chamber to minimize air contamination to sample surface. To overcome the charging problem, a charge neutralizer of 2eV was applied to make O(1s) peak shape and height as symmetrical as possible and the binding energy of C(1s) core level (BE 285eV) of adventitious hydrocarbon was used as a standard. Curve-fitted analysis was done using JEOL Specsurf software and XPSPEAK4.1 (UK Surface Analysis Forum). 2.2.7 X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) XAFS measurements were carried out at beam line 7C (BL7C) of Photon Factory (PF), in Institute of Materials Structure Science (IMSS), High Energy Accelerator Research Organization (KEK) in Japan, and at beam line 01B1 (BL01B1) at SPring 8 in Japan. The XAFS spectra were observed in transmittance and fluorescence mode and the collected data were analyzed by the software program REX2000 (Rigaku Co.). Curve fitting analysis was carried out with parameters obtained with FEFF8 (University of Washington). 2.2.8 Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) TPR profiles of the catalysts are obtained with Chemisorb 2720 (Micrometrics, USA) equipped with a TCD detector. The H2-TPR profiles are obtained by reducing the catalyst samples with 10% H2 in Ar at a flow rate of 20ml/min and the temperature is increased from ambient to 900°C at a rate of 10°C/min. For TPR, the catalysts were first reduced by a TPR run till 700°C. The gas was then switched to He and allowed to cool down at ambient temperature. Hydrogen consumptions in TPR profile were evaluated from the peak area of CuO TPR calibrations. 2.2.9 CO2-temperature programmed desorption (TPD) During TPD, the sample was heated under He flow from room temperature to 350°C for 30min. The dried catalysts were cooled to 80°C. CO2 uptake on the catalyst surface took place when the gas flow was changed to 5.2% CO2 in He. The CO2-TPD profile was obtained by a temperature programming under He with a flow rate of 20ml/min from ambient temperature to 1000°C at a temperature ramp of 10°C/min. The amounts of CO2 desorbed in the TPD peak area was evaluated by pulses of CO2 in a flow of He. 2.3 Catalyst activity for benzyl alcohol oxidation Benzyl alcohol oxidation was performed in a 50ml two necked round bottom flask following the procedure reported by Chowdhury et al. [26,27]. The reaction mixture was prepared by taking 4ml dry toluene, 4mmol benzyl alcohol and 0.1ml dodecane as an internal standard. The mixture was stirred using a magnetic stirrer and heated in a silicon oil bath using reflux condenser. The system was equipped with a thermocouple to control the temperature. The reaction mixture was shaken vigorously for homogenization and 0.1g catalyst was added to the mixture. Oxygen was bubbled into the mixture at 50ml/min (flow is maintained by Aalborg mass flow controller). In each reaction run, the mixture was heated to 90°C under vigorous stirring using polygon shape magnetic stirrer (stirring rate 260rpm). After 3h reaction time, the reaction mixture was analyzed in a GC (CIC-India) equipped with SE-30 column with FID detector. GC oven temperature was maintained at 200°C while injector and detector temperature was kept at 225°C. The conversion and selectivity are calculated by the following equation. The mass balance are calculated using standard equation (Fig. S1(a) and (b), Table S1: supporting information). Conversion ( % ) = [ Alcohol ] ( t = 0 ) − [ Alcohol ] ( t ) ] [ Alcohol ] ( t = 0 ) × 100 Selectivity ( % ) = Moles of product from Moles of alcohol converted × 100 where [Alcohol](t=0) is the initial concentration (mol) of benzyl alcohol and [Alcohol](t) is the final concentration (mol) of benzyl alcohol. 3 Results 3.1 BET S.A. and porosity measurement The results obtained from nitrogen physisorption analysis of the Mn–CeO2 (Mn/Ce=2/100), Mn–CeO2 (Mn/Ce=6/100) and 3.5wt% Au/Mn–CeO2 (Mn/Ce=6/100) catalyst are given in Table 1 . The adsorption isotherm and pore width distribution are presented in Fig. 1 . It shows that catalysts have type II isotherm texture similar as found for Ca–CeO2 prepared by similar method [26]. The adsorption–desorption isotherms show that the porosity of the catalysts are in the mesopore range (4–20nm). As per literature, the mesoporosity of the support allows easy access of reactants to the active sites and diffusion of products from the catalyst surface. It is observed that the textural property varies widely after Mn incorporation in comparison with the CeO2 prepared by same procedure (Fig. S2: supporting information). As reported in the literature [30] rapid deprotonation of [Ce(H2O) n (OH) y ](4−y)+ has a significant effect on the morphology of the nanocrystalline CeO2 powder as the [Ce(H2O) n (OH) y ](4−y)+ is polymeric in nature. As reported by Jiang et al. [31] TEA hinders the anisotropic growth of ZnO by adsorbing on its crystal plane and form microsphere. The BET surface area decreases after gold deposition which may be due to pore blocking of Mn–CeO2 support in this case. 3.2 X-ray diffraction (XRD) XRD patterns of representative catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . The catalyst exhibited XRD peaks of a typical cubic fluorite structure of CeO2. The crystallite size and lattice parameter of the catalyst samples are presented in Table 2 . The results in Table 2 showed that Mn-doping of CeO2 inhibits its crystallite growth but the lattice parameter is virtually remained unaffected. The similar trend was observed in our recent study where different alkali metal and rare earth metal were doped in the ceria matrix [26,27]. It implies that Mn-doping of CeO2 did not cause significant distortion of CeO2 fluorite structure. Another point to be noted that XRD patterns of the catalysts are virtually identical due to formation of Mn–CeO2 solid solution. Since lattice parameter of ceria fluorite structure is not significantly altered, we carried out HRTEM image analysis for 3.5wt% Au/Mn–CeO2 (Mn/Ce=6/100) catalyst only. 3.3 Raman spectra Characteristic Raman absorption band due to vibrational mode (F2g) of fluorite-type structure is very evident for the undoped CeO2 where a band appears at 465.26cm−1 (Fig. 3 ). It is generally agreed that this band results from symmetrical stretching vibration of the oxygen atoms around cerium ions [32–34]. There is a red shift of the band in the doped CeO2 materials. Extents of the shifts increases with the amounts of Mn-doping and also the presence of Au nanoparticles as observed in the spectra. Since ionic radius of Mn2+ ions is smaller than those of Ce4+ ions, the red shift of the F2g Raman band produced in gold free Mn-doped cerias may be attributed to constriction of fluorite structure due to the presence of Mn4+ ion. Further decrease of the F2g Raman band in the Au/Mn–CeO2 catalyst may be due to F2g mode softening phenomenon as reported by Lee et al. [35]. The phenomenon was found to be associated with increase in oxygen deficit and reactivity for CO oxidation. The Raman bands at higher wavelengths above the F2g band especially bands at 546cm−1 and 600cm−1 are generally attributed to surface defects. The band at 600cm−1 is ascribed to the intrinsic oxygen vacancies due to the presence of Ce3+ in ceria nanopowder. The band at 546cm−1 is usually assigned to oxygen vacancies generated for the charge balance when ceria is doped with trivalent cations [33,34]. The spectra of the gold containing catalyst showed Raman bands at 532.88, 617.65, 695.23cm−1, which suggests the increase of surface defects or oxygen vacancies in the catalyst. Interestingly, intensities of these bands in the gold free catalysts are very small. It is reported in literature that Au3+ (0.99Å) and Ce4+ (1.01Å) make a solid solution because of almost similar ionic radii [36]. This might be responsible for larger defects in 3.5wt% Au/Mn–CeO2 (Mn/Ce=6/100) catalyst. 3.4 High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and scanning tunneling electron microscopy (STEM) characterization The HRTEM images of the catalyst are presented in Fig. 4 . The image at lower magnification depicts a sponge-like 3D structure similar to what was obtained in our earlier studies [11]. High resolution image (b and c) revealed nanoparticles are of crystallites size ranges, i.e. 10–15nm which agree with XRD analysis. However the gold nanoparticles cannot be easily spotted in the HRTEM image revealing the residence of gold nanoparticles in the pores of Mn–CeO2. The distribution of the elements of Au/Mn–CeO2 catalyst is assayed by STEM analysis. Fig. 5 shows the elemental mapping obtained from the selected region of the material. The elemental mapping of Ce and O show a sponge-like matrix as obtained in HRTEM analysis also (Fig. 4). However distribution of Au nanoparticle is irregular and random in nature. It is an established fact that STEM with an HAADF mode is Z-contrasted one, i.e. the contrast of STEM image comes from the inelastic forward Rutherford electron scattering by the nucleus of the elements. As per the literature, inelastic scattering mode is proportional to Z 2, where Z represents the atomic number of the elements [37]. 3.5 Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) Chemical effects of Mn-doping and gold deposition on ceria are investigated with TPR technique. H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts are presented in Fig. 6 . Typical H2-TPR profile of pure CeO2 is characterized by the reduction peaks at 500°C and 800°C which are assigned to the surface capping oxide ions and the bulk oxygen, respectively [38]. Peaks at ≤500°C are ascribed to the reduction of surface capping oxide ions which is due to variation of the extent of coordination. This region of the profile is of particular interest for low temperature catalytic activities. In Fig. 6a lower temperature peaks appear in the profiles of Mn-doped catalysts. These peaks are assigned to MnO2 →Mn3O4 →MnO reduction [39]. Hydrogen consumption under these peaks are 5.5 and 3.7 times (for Mn/Ce=2/100 and 6/100, Mn-doped CeO2, respectively) higher than calculated amounts based on the proportion of Mn in the doped catalysts. Moreover, hydrogen consumption profile at 500°C region are similar for the four catalysts. As observed from XRD analysis the lattice parameter of ceria is essentially unaffected by Mn-doping so there is less distortion of the ceria present in fluorite phase. However, the Mn doping enhanced the reducibility of its host, i.e. CeO2 [6]. The profile of the Mn-doped CeO2 supported Au nanoparticle catalysts show reduction peak at 172°C. Interestingly no peak appear in the lower temperature region for Au/CeO2 catalyst as shown in Fig. 6. The hydrogen consumption profile of all the five catalysts (shown in Fig. S3: supporting information) indicate the enhanced reducibility after gold dipposition on Mn–CeO2 (Mn/Ce=6/100). As reported by Andreeva et al. [40] the peaks assigned to the ceria reduction were shifted to in the range of 120–150°C temperature. They have also described that the gold deposited CeO2–Al2O3 had more oxygen storage capacity as revealed in TPR study [40]. 3.6 CO2-temperature programmed desorption (TPD) The effect of Mn-doping and gold–support interaction on surface basicity of the ceria catalysts were examined using CO2-TPD techniques. Fig. 7 shows the CO2-TPD profiles of the four catalysts. In general the strength of the basic sites is obtained from desorption peak temperatures. The profiles depicted in Fig. 7 are made up of overlapping peaks but for easy quantitative comparison we demarcate the profiles into two regions, at ≤500°C and >500°C. The peaks at ≤500°C and >500°C are assigned as weak and strong basic sites, respectively. The basic sites distributions are presented in Fig. 8 . At 2mol% Mn doping of CeO2 the strong (basic) sites are absent whereas at higher Mn loading (6mol%) there is a redistribution in favour of strong basic sites. Positively charged metal centre are Lewis acidic sites while surface oxygen ions are the Bronsted basic sites on metal oxides [41]. Generally, basicity of a metal oxide depends on ionicity of the metal-oxygen bond. Ionic radius of Mn2+ cations are smaller (0.81Å) compared to those of Ce4+ (1.01Å). At 2mol% Mn-doping, the proportion of Mn in the lattice are not sufficient to produce detectable effect on the basicity of the lattice oxygens but at 6mol% Mn-doping the effect becomes measurable due to re-distribution of strong basic sites. Gold deposition on the CeO2 and Mn–CeO2 (Mn/Ce=6/100) support further alters the sites distribution. We rationalised the observation as due to the preferential adsorption of part of gold nanoparticles as Au δ+ clusters on the surface oxygen ions or strong basic sites. 3.7 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) The representative O(1s) spectrum of CeO2 and Mn doped CeO2 are presented in Fig. 9 . The O(1s) spectra consisted mainly of two peaks one at energy 529.0eV, another at 532.0eV. The peak at 532.0eV is due to Ce2O3 which is more covalent in nature. The another one at 529.0eV is oxygen present in CeO2 lattice [42]. As observed from Fig. 9 the peak corresponds to ionic oxygen shifts toward lower value in Au/Mn–CeO2 (Mn/Ce=6/100) catalyst in comparison with Au/CeO2 catalyst. This indicates the ionic oxygens are more labile in the case of Au/Mn–CeO2 (Mn/Ce=6/100) catalyst. Mn(2p) peaks of the catalysts (Fig. 10 ) indicates that Mn4+ is main Mn species for 2mol% and 6mol% Mn-doped ceria and Mn3+ was found for gold deposited 6% Mn-doped ceria (Table 3 ). As observed from the XPS analysis the core electron binding energy of Mn(2p) shifted to lower value for Au/Mn–CeO2 catalyst. It can be inferred that at higher manganese loading and after gold deposition the charge in the lattice was balanced with either oxygen vacancy or generation of electrophilic O− species. Partial reduction of Mn4+ to Mn3+ might generate potential oxygen activation site which can enhance the activity of the catalyst (Au/Mn–CeO2) towards alcohol oxidation reaction. Spin–orbit components (3d5/2 and 3d3/2) of 3d XPS spectra (Fig. 11 ) of Ce ions (Ce4+ and Ce3+) are characterised by multiplex peaks due to hybridisation of Ce (4f) orbitals with ligand orbitals [26]. The peaks around 882.1eV, 883.0eV, 888.7eV and 898.06eV are denoted as v 0, v, v′, v ‴ whereas peaks at 900.0eV, 901.4eV and 907.5 are denoted by u 0, u, u′ [42]. The peaks labeled as u are due to 3d3/2 spin–orbit states, and those labeled as v are due to the corresponding 3d5/2 states. The Ce (3d) spectrum basically denotes a mixture of Ce3+/Ce4+ oxidation states indicating that the surface of the sample is not fully oxidized [43]. While comparing the Ce (3d) peaks of Au/CeO2 and Au/Mn–CeO2 (Mn/Ce=6/100) the binding energy shifted to lower value indicating the effect of Mn to the gold-ceria interaction. The Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio changes with Mn incorporation and gold deposition on the ceria in the present study (Table S4(a)–(d): supporting information). It is also proposed that the concentration of oxygen vacancies in ceria is related to the particle sizes as smaller nanoparticles possess a higher concentration of oxygen vacancies. The hierarchically structured ceria fabricated in this work consists of nanosized crystals of ceria as building units which is evidenced from XRD and HRTEM investigations in the earlier section. Therefore a high concentration of the oxygen vacancy would be expected as reported by Loschen et al. for unsupported Ce n O2n−x (n) clusters [44]. By theoritical calculation they showed the formation of Ce3+ ions on the corner and edge sites, the relative amount of which increases with decreasing particle size. The XPS peaks for Au (4f) core electron (Fig. 12 ) are useful for studying the electronic state of surface gold nanoparticles [45,46]. In the present study Au/Mn–CeO2 shows Au 4f7/2 (83.3eV) and Au 4f5/2 (87.1eV) peaks due to 4f core level of gold. It is well documented in the literature that Au species present as metallic Au0, Au+ and Au3+ species on the support surface depending on the size of gold nanoparticles and the nature of supports. It is observed from Fig. 12 that binding energy of Au (4f) level shifts towards lower value facilitating formation of oxidic gold in the case Au/Mn–CeO2 (Mn/Ce=6/100) catalyst. As reported by Visco et al. [47] both Au0 and Au3+ species was found in Au/Fe2O3 catalyst whereas Soares et al. [48] reported that presence of metallic gold for Au/TiO2 catalysts prepared by the deposition–precipitation method. The unresolved issue is the oxidation state of the Au active site during oxidation reaction. Some researchers claim the ionic Au as the active species [49,50] hypothesizing a model proposed is an ensemble consisting of metallic Au and Au–OH species [51,52]. In contrast, other researchers proposal that active site is metallic Au, which is based on the fact that the only detectable species is metallic Au on an active catalyst. Till now to best of our knowledge there are few reports on the electronic state of Au during aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol. Baiker et al. reported the stability of oxidic gold for Cu–Mg–Al2O3 and CeO2 supported gold catalyst [53] during liquid phase oxidation of benzyl alcohol by using in situ XANES technique. 3.8 X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) To provide unambiguous evidence for the oxidation state of the metals in 3.5wt% Au/Mn–CeO2 (Mn/Ce=6/100) we turned to XANES spectroscopy. It is well known that spectral features of the near-edge region of the X-ray absorption spectra are affected by the oxidation state of the element studied and it provides a qualitative fingerprint of electronic structure and local atomic environment of the element. No oxidic gold was found for 3.5wt% Au/Mn–CeO2 catalyst as observed from XANES spectra (Fig. 13a). Fourier-transform k3 weighted Au L3 edge EXAFS spectrum of the catalyst is shown in Fig. 13b. Radial distribution curve analysis of the transform is characterised by signal in regions 2–3Å for Au–Au scatterings respectively. Low Au–Au signal is observed at 2.82±0.02Å (Au–Au in the gold foil is 2.84Å) and coordination number, 11.4, were obtained for the catalyst which is an evidence to the presence of gold nanoclusters on the catalyst surface [27]. 4 Catalytic activity studies The catalytic performance of Mn doped and undoped mesoporous CeO2 for aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol is summarized in Table 4 . Effect of Mn-doping on ceria appears optimum at Mn/Ce=6/100 molar ratio for the catalytic activity. It is interesting to note that Au/Mn–CeO2 (Mn/Ce=6/100) had higher activity compared to Au/CeO2. To examine the effect of gold nanoparticles several parameters like gold loading, precipitating agent, calcination temperature, concentration of gold precursor during deposition–precipitation was varied during preparation (Table S5–S8: supporting information). The change in the catalytic activity was observed in all these studies demonstrating the promotional role of gold nanoparticle during benzyl alcohol oxidation using molecular oxygen as an oxidant. The recycling of the catalyst is very important for industrial applications. After washing with diethyl ether and calcined at 300°C, we could reuse Au/Mn–CeO2 (Mn/Ce=6/100) catalyst with 3.5wt% Au for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol. The activity and the selectivity to benzaldehyde was almost unchanged after first recycling but in case of second recycling the conversion was decreased to 24.87% without changing the selectivity of benzaldehyde (Fig. 14 ). The decrease of benzyl alcohol conversion may be due to the growth of gold nanoparticles. 5 Discussion The result obtained from XRD studies indicate that lattice parameter of the fluorite structure of CeO2 did not change significantly with Mn-doping. TPR results show that Mn-doping enhances redox cycle capacity of ceria whereas TPD results also revealed that surface basicity of CeO2 increased with Mn doping. Thus, the distortion effect of Mn-doping on the lattice of CeO2 is electronic in nature. The combined effects account for the enhanced activity of the Mn–CeO2 catalysts. The performance of the catalysts for alcohol oxidation can be correlated with redox cycle capacity of the doped oxide catalyst. The role of acid–base properties of the catalysts on their activity is also noticeable. It has been proven in the literature that oxidative dehydrogenation of alcohols to aldehydes occurs on metal oxides catalyst [54]. The conversion involved the initial alkoxy intermediate formation on weak Lewis acid–strong Bronsted base site pairs. But the reaction is limited by the removal of hydrogen. It has been observed that not only basic sites but also acidic sites are present for all the catalyst as found in the NH3-TPD results (Fig. S9, Fig. S10: supporting information). The reaction followed Mars–Van Krevelen mechanism and the rate of replenishing the used surface oxygen ions constitute the rate limiting step. As observed in our characterization results the doping of manganese alters acid–base sites distributions thereby increasing the activity towards the oxidation reaction. Expectedly, Au deposition enhances the catalytic performance of the doped and undoped CeO2 catalysts, however, it is difficult to define the role of Au in each case since the doped and undoped CeO2 is active and selective for aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol. Activity of supported gold catalysts is generally ascribed to particle size and geometry [55–58]. It has been demonstrated that hydride abstraction is the rate-determining step in gold-catalyzed aerobic oxidation of alcohols [59]. It has also been shown that O–H bonds activation by a base or basic sites has synergistic effect with hydride abstraction by noble metals for aerobic oxidation of alcohol in aqueous alkaline media [60]. The rate determining step (abstraction of hydride ion from deprotonated alcohol) of aerobic alcohol oxidation can take place by surface active oxygen species or oxygen vacancy sites of the metal oxides as observed in the gold free catalysts. It is observed in our recent study on Ba2+, Ca2+, Mg2+ incorporated Au/CeO2 catalyst that alteration of basic sites had a prominent role in the catalytic activity for benzyl alcohol oxidation reaction [26]. In the present case we have observed that basic sites of Mn–CeO2 catalyst alter with increase in Mn doping and gold deposition. CeO2 has lowest oxygen uptake capacity, suggesting CeO2 has the lowest density of oxygen vacancy sites. Hence, comparison of the activities of CeO2 and Au/CeO2 (Table 4) suggests that Au nanoparticles as oxygen activation sites are also the main hydride abstraction sites. Another important observation is about the role of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface. The oxygen vacancies first originated in the surface upon water elimination. The possibility could be the presence of Ce3+ which favoured the formation of oxygen vacancies in the mixed oxide surface [61]. It can be speculated that a chemical pumping effect causes oxygen to diffuse up to the surface reaching the vacant sites. As discussed in the reported [62] studies, the reduction of ceria is proposed to be controlled by the nature of the oxygen vacancies since oxygen diffusion is the rate-controlling step. 6 Conclusion In conclusion a highly mesoporous (pore diameter >15nm) Mn doped ceria material which is used as a support for gold nanoparticle was prepared by a modified sol–gel method. The physicochemical properties of the Mn–CeO2 material were characterized by different techniques. From the XRD analysis there is no structural distortion for doped ceria which is present as a nanocrystalline solid solution. As found from XPS studies, the Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio changes with Mn doping and gold deposition. Deposition of gold nanoparticles and Mn-doping on the ceria surface enhanced its redox property during aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol. Gold nanoparticles change the reducibility of ceria as found from H2-TPR whereas mostly alteration in the basic sites is observed from CO2-TPD study. The XAFS analysis showed that gold is present mostly as metallic clusters. The catalytic activity showed the promotional effect of Au and Mn for benzyl alcohol oxidation reaction using molecular O2. coredata.dc:description: In this decade intensive research was carried out to prepare mesoporous non-silicious oxide for various application. Development of mesoporous ceria based material has become most important because of its application in catalysis, solar cell and photovoltic cell. The selective aerobic oxidation of primary alcohols through an environment benign route to synthesize aldehydes is of utmost importance. The catalytic role of supported gold nanoparticles for aerobic oxidation reaction has been focused in the era of sustainable chemistry. The unique redox property of ceria is a fascination for developing Au–CeO2 catalyst in many studies on aerobic oxidation reaction. In this work, we have prepared mesoporous manganese doped ceria to examine the change of physicochemical properties due to incorporation of managnese to the ceria lattice. Deposition of gold nanoparticles and Mn-doping on ceria enhanced the redox behaviour of ceria as well as the basic properties. A thorough characterization by BET S.A., XRD, Raman, HRTEM, STEM, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, XPS, XAFS reveal the distortion of in the doped CeO2 lattice is electronic in nature rather than structural distortion. The catalytic activity of the catalysts demonstrate the promotional role of gold nanoparticle in this study.
